Lead (Pb) is a typical heavy metal in the flue gas of coal-fired power plants, which can cause the deactivation of SCR catalysts. In this study, Pb-doped vanadium-based catalysts were prepared and investigated for the deactivation effect and mechanism of elemental Hg oxidation caused by Pb. The results showed that doping Pb on vanadium-based catalysts led to severe deactivation, which was more pronounced with increased Pb content. Further investigation illustrated that the introduction of Pb not only weakened the BET surface properties of vanadium-based catalysts but also increased the aggregation of surface species on the catalysts. After Pb introduction, the adsorption capacity toward elemental Hg, proportion of highly oxidized V5+, and surface Oβ ratio significantly decreased severely weakening the activity of the catalyst. In addition, we demonstrated that the reaction between Pb and active VO/V−OH groups of the catalyst formed inactive V−O−Pb species, which was the direct cause of catalyst deactivation. Among these, Hg (primarily in the form of elemental Hg, Hg0) may have significant adverse effects on human health and the environment due to its persistence, bioaccumulation, and genetic toxicity [1], making it the primary control target of flue gas pollution [2]. As a primary source of Hg, coal-fired power plants typically utilize selective catalytic reduction (SCR) devices as a multi-pollutant synergistic control technology to achieve flue gas denitration and Hg removal [3–5]. However, SCR devices are typically arranged in a high-concentration dust section, and loaded catalysts are typically exposed to large amounts of fly ash for long periods, resulting in the issue of chemical deactivation (poisoning) caused by PM [6,7]. Due to their excellent performance, traditional V2O5-WO3/TiO2 SCR catalysts are widely used for denitration and Hg removal from fixed combustion sources, especially in coal-fired power plants [8]. Research on SCR catalyst poisoning in coal-fired power plants demonstrated that fly ash in the flue gas can cause catalyst poisoning, including alkali metals (e.g., Na and K) [9] and heavy metals (e.g., lead (Pb) and As) [10,11]. In terms of the poisoning mechanism of catalysts caused by alkali metals, previous studies showed that acidic sites on a catalyst surface could react with alkali metal ions, causing changes in the active center of the catalyst. This affected the adsorption and conversion of the reducing agent NH3 species on the catalyst surface, leading to catalyst deactivation [12]. Similar to alkali metals, coal-fired flue gas also contains significant amounts of Pb [13]. Pb in the flue gas exists primarily in the form of PbO [14], with a small portion present in the form of PbCl2 [15]. A study on multiple coal-fired power plants demonstrated that the concentration ranges of particulate-bound Pb and gas-phase Pb in the flue gas reached 1450–5760 and 230–570 μg/m3, respectively [16]. Pb had a tendency to accumulate on the catalyst surface, forming inactive bonds with vanadia species, severely impairing the activity of the SCR catalyst. A previous study also demonstrated that the deactivation of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts caused by Pb was primarily due to chemical reactions rather than pore blockages [17], and Pb had a tendency to neutralize the surface acidic sites of vanadium-based catalysts, inhibiting the activation of NH3 molecules and severely impairing SCR activities [18]. These studies have mainly focused on the denitration process, with relatively few studies on catalyst deactivation during Hg oxidation, and even fewer studies on Pb poisoning during this process. Therefore, it is important to further study whether the introduction of Pb can obstruct the Hg catalytic reaction over SCR catalysts, along with the main effects and how they hinder the Hg oxidation reaction. As a result, experimental and characterization studies were conducted on vanadium-based catalyst deactivation caused by Pb in simulated coal-fired flue gas. This study aimed to clarify the effects of Pb on the Hg0 catalytic oxidation process by observing the changes in Hg oxidation efficiency, surface characteristics, Hg adsorption capacity, and surface redox capacity before and after catalyst deactivation. We also elucidated the interactions between Pb and key active centers of the catalysts. Subsequently, the Pb poisoning mechanism on vanadium-based catalysts was proposed. Furthermore, this study aimed to obtain scientific evidence of catalyst deactivation caused by Pb during the Hg oxidation process and provide additional insights into improving the Pb resistance ability of catalysts. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation All catalysts in this work were prepared using the wet impregnation method. The V2O5(1)-WO3(9)/TiO2 catalysts (the numerals in brackets represent the mass percentage and are abbreviated as V1W9/Ti) were prepared by dispersing a certain mass of commercial TiO2 (Degussa P25) powder into a mixture of ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3) and ammonium paratungstate [(NH4)10(W12O41)·5 H2O] oxalic solution at the desired proportions to obtain a slurry. The slurry was then stirred for 24 h and heated to 110 °C for 12 h followed by calcination at 500 °C for 4 h in air. The catalysts to simulate Pb poisoning were obtained by immersing the desired amount of lead nitrate [Pb(NO3)2] solution into the previously prepared V1W9/Ti catalyst denoted as Pbx-V1W9/Ti, where x represents the mass percentage. The Pb-doped slurries were also stirred for 24 h, dried at 110 °C for 12 h, and finally calcinated at 500 °C for 4 h. All catalyst samples were ground and sieved through a 40–60 mesh for activity evaluation. 2.2 Activity measurement Assembly of the simulated Hg0 oxidation test setup consisted of a DynaCal Hg0 permeation device (VICI Metronics, USA), a flue gas simulation system, a packed-bed reactor, an online Hg analyzer, and a data acquisition system, with the schematic shown in Fig. 1. A flow of pure N2 passed the permeation tube and yielded a stable concentration of Hg0 at the desired temperature, as long as the flow rate and water bath temperature were stable. The flue gas components were simulated using cylinder gas with the desired concentration, and the flow rate was controlled using a mass flow controller. The reactor consisted of a U-shaped quartz tube with an outer diameter of 8 mm and an inner diameter of 6 mm, which was held in a vertical position and surrounded by a clamshell furnace. A temperature control device was employed to maintain the reactor at the desired temperature. Simulated gas passed the bypass holder and determined the baseline Hg0 concentration. Once thermal stability was reached, simulated gas was diverted to pass through the catalysts for the Hg0 oxidation tests. The Hg0 oxidation tests were conducted using an inlet gas stream of 200 mL/min to pass through 0.1 g of catalyst during the activity measurements. The basic composition of the inlet gas contained 80 μg/m3 Hg0, 6 % O2, and balanced with N2. Tests were conducted at a temperature range of 100–500 °C, and all tubing was heated to a constant temperature of 120 °C to prevent adsorption and condensation. The Hg0 concentrations of the influent and effluent were measured by switching an RA 915 Hg analyzer (Lumex Inc., Russia) at the beginning and the end of each test, and Hg0 oxidation was calculated according to the measurements. Hg0 oxidation efficiency (E oxi ) over the catalysts was expressed and calculated using the inlet/outlet Hg0 concentrations according to the following equation: (1) E o x i = H g i n l e t 0 − H g o u t l e t 0 H g i n l e t 0 × 100 % . The effective tests of flue gas components such as HCl, NO, SO2, NH3, and water vapor (H2O) were subsequently performed, and an online detector was used to continuously measure the concentration (KM9106, Kane Inc.). The instrument was calibrated before each test for quality assurance and quality control. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, pore size, and pore volume were measured by N2 adsorption at 77 K using an ASAP 2460 system (Micromeritics Inc., USA). X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted using a D/max-2500 X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Inc., Japan) using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation. During analysis, the samples were scanned from 10° to 90°, and the microstructures of the catalysts were observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using an SU8010 instrument (Hitachi, Japan). The samples were sprayed with gold using a Hitachi MC1000 instrument, and the energy spectrum model of the Horiba EMAX mics system utilized a voltage of 3.0 kV. Temperature-programmed desorption of the Hg (Hg-TPD) measurements was conducted using 0.1 g of catalyst in a quartz reactor. Adsorption was performed by passing a gas mixture containing 200 μg/m3 Hg0 with N2 through the sample bed at 25 °C with a total flow rate of 200 mL/min. The experiment consisted of three stages. First, the sample was swept in N2 at 500 °C for 2 h; and then, adsorption of Hg0 was performed for 48 h until the Hg vapor throughout the samples and the concentrations were equal before/after catalyst exposure; after that, TPD measurements were conducted up to 500 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min with a total flow rate of 200 mL/min N2. The Hg0 concentration was continuously recorded using an online RA 915 Hg analyzer. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were obtained using a Quantera SXM instrument (ULVAC-PHI Inc., Japan). The binding energies referenced the C 1 s line at 284.8 eV from adventitious carbon. Raman spectra tests were measured using a Raman microscope (InVia Reflex, Renishaw) equipped with a deep-depleted thermoelectrically cooled charge-coupled device array detector and a high-grade Leica microscope. The 532 nm line of the laser was used for recording the Raman spectra. The samples were pretreated in N2 flow at 300°C for 1 h, and then were cooled to 250°C for spectrum collection. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) in the H2 analysis experiments was conducted with an AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics Inc., USA) using approximately 0.1 g of sample. The samples were pretreated at 300°C for 1 h under N2 flow. The temperature was linearly increased from 100°C to 900°C at 10 °C/min, and H2 consumption, with a concentration of 10 %, was continuously recorded. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of Pb on Hg0 oxidation performance 3.1.1 Pb loading Fig. 2 shows the Hg0 oxidation efficiencies over the V1W9/Ti catalyst and those doped with different loadings of Pb in the temperature range of 100–500°C. As expected, when the reaction temperature was increased in the range of 100–500°C, the Hg0 oxidation efficiency over all catalysts showed a similar trend, gradually increasing in the temperature range of 100–400°C, reaching a peak at approximately 350–400°C, and then decreasing in the temperature range of 400–500°C. We also observed that the Hg0 oxidation efficiency was significantly higher over the V1W9/Ti catalyst than over the Pb-doped catalysts. During the reaction temperature range of 200–400°C, the Hg0 oxidation efficiency over the V1W9/Ti catalyst was approximately 91 %, while over the Pb1-V1W9/Ti catalyst, it was 83 %. The results also indicated the Hg0 oxidation efficiency over the poisoned catalysts gradually decreased as the Pb loading increased. The average Hg0 oxidation efficiencies over the Pb1-V1W9/Ti, Pb3-V1W9/Ti, and Pb5-V1W9/Ti catalysts at approximately 200–400°C were 83 %, 78 %, and 69 %, respectively; therefore, the Hg0 oxidation efficiencies over the Pb-poisoned catalysts decreased by 9 %, 14 %, and 22 %, respectively, compared with that over the V1W9/Ti catalyst. Therefore, we observed that the introduction of Pb inhibited the activities of the V1W9/Ti catalyst, and with increased Pb loading, the catalyst deactivation became more severe. 3.1.2 Flue gas component In order to investigate the deactivation effect by Pb under flue gas conditions, we conducted Hg0 oxidation activity tests over the V1W9/Ti and Pb1-V1W9/Ti catalysts under different concentrations of flue gas components including O2, HCl, NO, SO2, NH3, and H2O. The results are shown in Fig. 3, and the detailed results are summarized and discussed in the following text. 3.1.2.1 Enhancement effect of O2 and HCl O2 and HCl, as the main reactants, have been shown to play a positive role in the catalytic oxidation of flue gas Hg0 [4]. In this experiment, when the O2 concentration increased from 2 % to 10 %, the Hg0 oxidation efficiency over the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts slowly increased and eventually stabilized at 49 % and 35 %, respectively. However, after the introduction of 5–40 ppm HCl, the Hg0 oxidation efficiency on the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts significantly increased, reaching 92 % and 81 %, respectively. This indicated that O2 and HCl independently participated in the oxidation of Hg0, greatly improving the catalytic oxidation efficiency, and the oxidation process of Hg0 was similar for the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts. Notably, the Hg0 catalytic oxidation reaction on the metal oxides with the participation of O2 followed the Mars-Maessen (MM) mechanism [19]. Among these, the surface lattice oxygen of the metal oxides served as the oxidant of Hg0, forming mercuric oxide (HgO). Gas-phase O2, however, re-oxidized the reduced metal oxides and replenished the surface lattice oxygen [20]. The redox cycle could be summarized as follows: (2) V2O5 + Hg → V2O4 + HgO, (3) V2O4 + 1/2O2 → V2O5. However, due to the presence of HCl, the Hg0 catalytic oxidation reaction on the catalyst surface followed the Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism or Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism, with the main difference consisting of the adsorption sites of Hg0 and HCl on the catalyst surface [21]. Among these, HCl interacted with the VO site of the catalyst surface to form Cl−V5+−OH, and the active Cl species subsequently oxidized the adsorbed Hg0 to generate HgCl2, which was released into the flue gas [22]. These reactions can occur by (4) V=O + HCl ↔ Cl−V−OH, (5) Hg(ads) + 2Cl−V−OH → HgCl2 + 2 V−OH. 3.1.2.2 Promotional effect of NO and SO2 Similar to O2 and HCl, when the NO concentration increased from 100 to 800 ppm, the Hg0 oxidation efficiency over the V1W9/Ti and Pb1-V1W9/Ti catalysts gradually increased and eventually stabilized at 66 % and 47 %, indicating the promotional effect of NO on Hg0 oxidation over both catalysts. Previous research reported that NO adsorbed as nitrosyl and dinitrosyl surface species on reduced vanadia surfaces. The adsorbed NO could be oxidized on the catalyst surface, resulting in species such as NO, NO+ 2, and NO3–, or it could be reduced by the reduced catalyst centers [20]. These adsorbed species that derived from NO were likely responsible for the observed Hg0 oxidation. As shown in Fig. 3, SO2 had a significant promotional effect on Hg0 oxidation over both catalysts. When the concentration of SO2 increased from 200 to 1200 ppm, the Hg0 oxidation efficiency over the V1W9/Ti and Pb1-V1W9/Ti catalysts increased from 55 % to 60 % and from 40 % to 44 %, respectively. In the literature, the effect of SO2 on Hg0 oxidation in flue gas was reported as either exhibiting promotional or inhibitory effects [7,23]. Most studies indicated that due to the affinity of O and S toward Hg, the oxidation of Hg0 was often promoted when SO2 and O2 were present in the flue gas [24]. In our previous study, we demonstrated that SO2 would be adsorbed or oxidized on the catalyst surface, enhancing the adsorption of Hg0 on the catalyst surface, and thereby promoting the Hg0 oxidation efficiency [25]. 3.1.2.3 Inhibitory effect of NH3 and H2O When 100–800 ppm NH3 and 2–10 % H2O were introduced into the flue gas, the Hg0 oxidation efficiencies over the V1W9/Ti and Pb1-V1W9/Ti catalysts were significantly reduced below 25 % and 15 %, respectively, indicating the inhibitory effects of NH3 and H2O on Hg0 oxidation over the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts. We observed that the inhibitory effect of H2O was more noticeable. Previous research indicated that NH3 occupied the acidic sites on the catalyst surface [26], thereby inhibiting the Hg0 oxidation process by the catalyst. Meanwhile, the inhibition of H2O was attributed to H2O competing with Hg0 for the same active sites on the catalyst surface [20]. Therefore, based on the above results and discussion, we believe that the deactivation of Hg0 oxidation over the V1W9/Ti catalyst caused by Pb still exists under different flue gas components conditions, and the deactivation seems to be less affected by the flue gas components, but more likely due to the interaction between Pb and V, O active species, thereby changing the physical and chemical properties of the catalysts. 3.2 Effect of Pb on the physicochemical properties of the catalysts 3.2.1 BET, XRD, and SEM results Table 1 summarizes the physical properties, including the BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameters of the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts. The BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of V1W9/Ti were slightly reduced after Pb doping, and similar results also appeared as the Pb loading increased. This indicated that the introduction of Pb slightly reduced the BET surface properties of the V1W9/Ti catalyst. By comparing these results to the Hg0 catalytic oxidation activities, we concluded that the introduction of Pb slightly reduced the BET surface properties of the catalyst, which affected the Hg0 oxidation efficiency. Therefore, the higher the Pb loading of the catalyst, the more pronounced the decrease in BET surface properties and Hg0 oxidation efficiency. The XRD patterns of the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts were measured, and Fig. 4 shows the results. In all catalyst samples, the major feature of the XRD patterns consisted of typical peaks of anatase TiO2 and WO3. Another feature was that no characteristic VOx peaks were observed in the XRD profiles, indicating that VOx was amorphous/highly dispersed in the TiO2 support on the catalyst surface. Further observations indicate that the XRD patterns of the Pb-poisoned catalysts exhibit two distinct peaks near the angles of 27.5°, which are attributed to the diffraction peaks of PbO and Pb2O3 [17]. With increased Pb loading, the diffraction peaks of Pb oxide became more obvious, which correlated well with the catalytic activity results. Therefore, we concluded that Pb is mainly dispersed on the catalyst surface in the form of oxides, and its introduction slightly changes the crystal structure of V1W9/Ti catalyst. Fig. 5 shows the SEM images of the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts under 1.0×105 times magnification. The results indicated that the surface morphologies of the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts were similar, mainly in the form of TiO2 crystal clusters. However, the Pb-poisoned catalysts exhibited more crystalline phases and surface species clusters than the V1W9/Ti catalyst, and with increased Pb loading, surface species aggregation became more obvious, which was well correlated with the BET results. The aggregates would affect the catalyst surface characteristics by covering and occupying the exposed active sites, which was unfavorable to the surface’s physical and chemical properties [27]. 3.2.2 Hg-TPD results Fig. 6 shows the Hg-TPD profiles of the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts, and Table 2 summarizes the Hg-TPD results. We observed that all catalysts displayed desorption peaks that represented different adsorption capacities. Two desorption peaks for the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts were observed at approximately 160−220°C and 260−280°C, which indicated that two-stage Hg0 adsorption occurred on the catalyst surface. For the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts, Hg desorption peaked at 150–200°C, which was caused by the decomposition of weakly adsorbed species [28]. The Hg desorption peaks were also separately observed at 260–280°C, which could be ascribed to strongly bound species [25]. Previous research confirmed that Hg0 adsorbed on vanadium-based catalyst surfaces in the form of Hg···O−V4+ [23], according to the following process: (6) Hg(g) + O=V5+ → Hg(ads, Hg⋯O−V4+). Surface adsorption plays an important role in chemical reactions because it generally consists of the first step of a catalytic reaction, with the surface adsorption phase also occurring at reaction active sites [29]. Research based on density functional theory analysis indicated that the more Hg⋯O−V adsorbed at this stage, the greater the possibility of subsequent oxidation [30]. Another observation was that Pb doping caused a decrease in the desorption peak area of the catalysts. As shown in Table 2, the corresponding Hg0 desorption amounts of the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts were 197 (V1W9/Ti), 142 (Pb1-V1W9/Ti), 105 (Pb3-V1W9/Ti), and 92 µmol/g (Pb5-V1W9/Ti). The results illustrated that Pb doping significantly weakened the surface Hg0 adsorption capacity of the catalysts, preventing more Hg0 from entering the first step of the catalytic reaction. Compared with the catalytic performance results, a good correlation was observed between the Hg0 desorption amount and the oxidation efficiency, especially as the Pb loading increased. Therefore, the Hg0 oxidation efficiency over the Pb-poisoned catalysts gradually decreased. 3.2.3 XPS results Fig. 7(a) and (b), respectively, shows the V2p and O1s spectrum results of the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts, and Table 3 lists the surface-active atomic proportions of the catalysts. The V2p spectrum exhibited a typical V1W9/Ti XPS pattern, with the V species evenly spread and effectively covered on the catalyst surface. Several obvious peaks were observed in the range of 516.0–517.0 eV. According to previous work [31], the binding energies at approximately 517.2 eV and 516.2 eV correlated to V2O5 and V2O4, respectively, suggesting that V was distributed on the catalyst surface as a mixture of V5+ and V4+. It has been reported that the high proportion of V5+ on the catalyst surface could directly lead to the high activity of the catalyst [31]. The results of the surface V valence state indicated that the proportion of highly oxidized V5+ on the V1W9/Ti catalyst surface was 66 %, which was higher than those in the Pb1-V1W9/Ti (57 %), Pb3-V1W9/Ti (52 %), and Pb5-V1W9/Ti (46 %) (Table3). During the Hg0 catalytic oxidation process, V5+=O served as an important active site [29]. It has been reported that the inhibitory effects of Pb to V5+ may be due to the extension of VO bonds caused by interactions between V and Pb, causing Pb ions to react with V5+=O and form V4+−O−Pb [12], and this process can be summarized as follows: (7) Pb + V=O → V−O−Pb. In the ER or LH mechanisms, due to the participation of HCl, the adsorbed activated Cl reacted with V−OH to form Cl−V−O [22]. After Pb was deposited on the catalyst surface, Pb subsequently combined with one or two acid sites on vanadium-based catalysts to form Cl−V−O−Pb [18], according to the following reaction: (8) Pb + Cl−V−O → Cl−V−O−Pb. Whether following the MM or ER/LH reaction mechanisms, the decrease in vanadium oxygen double bonds (V5+=O) indicated an increase in vanadium oxygen single bonds (V4+−O), and this increase implied the inevitable formation of more V−O−Pb on the catalyst surface. Fig. 7(b) shows that significant peaks of O1s were detected in the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts and that these peaks were fitted into two types, namely, lattice oxygen at approximately 530.1 eV (denoted as Oα) and chemisorbed oxygen belonging to defect-oxide or hydroxyl-like groups at approximately 531.6 eV (denoted as Oβ) [32]. It was reported that Oα and Oβ could supply oxygen source for elemental mercury oxidation over the SCR catalyst [32]. From the results of O1s, it can be seen that after the addition of Pb, the Oα on the catalyst shifted 0.1–0.3 eV to the higher binding energy respectively, indicating that Pb blocked the source of some surface oxygen, making it more difficult to obtain lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface. Additionally, surface chemisorbed oxygen is considered to be consists of a type of very active oxygen, and the relatively high concentration ratio of Oβ/(Oα+Oβ) on the catalyst surface can be correlated with high oxidation activity [33]. The results showed that the surface Oβ ratios of the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts were 26 % (V1W9/Ti), 20 % (Pb1-V1W9/Ti), 17 % (Pb3-V1W9/Ti), and 14 % (Pb5-V1W9/Ti). Notably, the introduction of Pb reduced the Oβ distribution on the catalyst surface, where the higher loading of Pb led to lower surface Oβ ratios, which was in accordance with the Hg0 catalytic activities. Previous studies noted that Pb could react with surface active species such as chemisorbed oxygen, destroying the original oxygen defects on the catalyst surface [12]. Therefore, it can be inferred that the decrease in surface oxygen of the catalyst is due to the strong interaction with Pb. 3.2.4 Raman spectroscopy results To further investigate the interaction between Pb and the surface active center (V5+=O) on the catalysts, Raman spectroscopy experiments were conducted on the fresh and Pb-poisoned catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 8. There were five primary peaks observed in V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts at 145, 200, 395, 515, and 637 cm−1. All these peaks were derived from TiO2 [34]. After Pb poisoning, the peak of the catalysts weakened, indicating that Pb poisoning promoted the crystallization of fresh catalyst and weakened the dispersion of the components, which correlated well with the SEM results. Additionally, a weak Raman peak was observed at 1045 cm−1, and the peak intensity gradually weakened with increasing Pb loading. Previous studies reported that the absorption band at near 1048 cm−1 was ascribed to the VO stretching vibration in the active component V2O5 of the catalyst [6]. The weakening of the stretching vibration peak intensity here means that the VO bond was consumed, thereby indicating that Pb ions interacted with some VO bonds in the poisoned catalysts and formed V−O−Pb bands. This further confirms the Pb reaction occurred on the catalyst surface according to Eq. (7). 3.2.5 H2-TPR results In order to further find out the redox process and identify intermediate species in the reaction between Pb and V, O on the catalyst surface, we conducted the H2-TPR experiments to the V1W9/Ti and Pb-poisoned catalysts, with the results presented in Fig. 9. The H2-TPR profiles revealed two obvious H2 consumption regions at 450–550°C and 750–850°C, with the former ascribed to the reduction of vanadium species, and the latter belonging to the reduction of tungsten species [9]. It is generally believed that low reduction peak temperatures of V5+ and W6+ will be beneficial for catalytic reaction cycles [35]. However, Pb doping significantly changed the reduction peaks of V5+ and W6+ to higher temperatures. The H2 consumption peak temperatures of V5+ and W6+ in the V1W9/Ti catalyst were approximately 495°C and 765°C, respectively, while those of the Pb1-V1W9/Ti catalysts shifted to higher temperatures of 502°C and 780°C, respectively. Similar results were also observed for other Pb-poisoned catalysts. The results indicated that as the Pb loading of the catalyst increases, the reducibility of vanadium species in the poisoned catalysts gradually decreased, which was consistent with the catalytic performance results. In addition, the H2-TPR results showed an additional H2 consumption peak in the temperature range of 600–650°C for the Pb-poisoned catalysts, corresponding to temperatures of 603°C, 615°C, and 638°C for the three samples. It was reported that the peak of H2 consumption of poisoned SCR catalysts occurred at approximately 600°C, originating from oxygen-bonded Pb species and corresponding to the reduction of Pb2+ to Pb0 [11]. Another reduction peak was observed at 560°C for the Pb1-V1W9/Ti catalyst, at 565°C for the Pb3-V1W9/Ti catalyst, and at 590°C for the Pb5-V1W9/Ti catalyst. According to the literature [12], the difference between the reduction temperatures of VOx and PbO was originated from the V−O−Pb band, which formed by the reaction of Pb ions with active center species (VO/V−OH) on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the H2-TPR results further confirmed the reaction based on Eq. (7) between Pb and vanadium species, mainly through the combination of Pb with active center VO/V−OH to form V−O−Pb species, which is consistent with the Raman spectroscopy results. However, the reduction peak originating from the V−O−Pb band on the Pb1-V1W9/Ti catalyst was not sufficiently obvious, possibly due to low content or overlap with the reduction peak of PbO [35]. 3.3 Pb poisoning mechanism of the catalysts As discussed in section 3.1.2, the oxidation process of Hg0 over the vanadium-based catalysts generally followed a heterogeneous oxidation mechanism, including the MM, ER, or LH mechanisms. In the MM mechanism, Hg0 was adsorbed on the catalyst surface in the form of Hg···O−V, and then the surface oxygen could oxidize Hg0, forming HgO. Subsequently, gas-phase O2 oxidized the reduced metal oxides, replenishing the surface oxygen, according to Eqs. (2) and (3). In the ER or LH mechanisms, HCl interacted with the VO site of the catalyst surface to form Cl−V−OH, and the active Cl species subsequently oxidized the adsorbed Hg0 to generate HgCl2, according to Eqs. (4) and (5). Accordingly, paths (i) and (iii) in Fig. 10 describe the oxidation and chlorination interactions of Hg0 and V2O5 on the catalyst surface. Following analysis of the physicochemical properties of the catalysts and related chemical reactions, we proposed a catalyst poisoning mechanism caused by Pb over the vanadium-based catalysts during the Hg0 catalytic oxidation process, which is illustrated as paths (ii), (iv), and (v) in Fig. 10. Although Pb was deposited on the surfaces of the vanadium-based catalysts, Pb combined with one or two active sites (VO/V−OH) to form V−O−Pb according to path (ii). As a result, these active sites lost their ability to adsorb Hg0. With the participation of HCl, it reacted with VO to form Cl−V−OH groups. The generated and adjacent Cl−V−OH groups proceeded to react with Pb and form Cl−V−O−Pb according to path (iv), resulting in the deactivation of the active sites of VO/V−OH. Additionally, the absorbed Hg0 could further react with Cl−V−O−Pb to form inactive V−O−Pb groups and HgCl2 according to path (v). Subsequently, the unsaturated V−OH groups in steps (i) and (iii) reacted with surface Oβ to generate fresh active sites (VO), and the reaction cycle was established. 4 Conclusions Doping Pb on V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts resulted in serious deactivation during the elemental Hg oxidation process, and deactivation caused by Pb was positively correlated with Pb loading. The experimental results indicated that the doping of Pb caused significant changes in the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst surface, including a decrease in the Hg0 adsorption capacity, a decrease in the concentration of surface strong oxidants V5+, and a decrease in the surface Oβ ratio. Further investigation confirmed that Pb reacted with the active VO/V−OH groups of the catalyst to form inactive V−O−Pb species, which was the direct cause of catalyst deactivation, and a poisoning mechanism of the catalysts caused by Pb was proposed according to these results. coredata.dc:description: Lead (Pb) is a typical heavy metal in the flue gas of coal-fired power plants, which can cause the deactivation of SCR catalysts. In this study, Pb-doped vanadium-based catalysts were prepared and investigated for the deactivation effect and mechanism of elemental Hg oxidation caused by Pb. The results showed that doping Pb on vanadium-based catalysts led to severe deactivation, which was more pronounced with increased Pb content. Further investigation illustrated that the introduction of Pb not only weakened the BET surface properties of vanadium-based catalysts but also increased the aggregation of surface species on the catalysts. After Pb introduction, the adsorption capacity toward elemental Hg, proportion of highly oxidized V5+, and surface Oβ ratio significantly decreased severely weakening the activity of the catalyst. In addition, we demonstrated that the reaction between Pb and active VO/V−OH groups of the catalyst formed inactive V−O−Pb species, which was the direct cause of catalyst deactivation.
